title: China dependency good for trade: Frydenberg
text:
Despite a gradual slide in the bilateral relationship over the last five years, China has not punished Australia in any meaningful economic way for the banning of Huawei, the enacting of foreign interference legislation or Canberra's push-back against Beijing's growing strategic ambitions.

China has become increasingly reliant on Australian energy and mineral exports as the trade war with the United States rumbles on, crimping Beijing's ability to penalise Canberra for its tougher stance on national security issues.

Australia supplied 46 per cent of China's LNG imports in the year to June, more than any other country and up from the previous year, just as demand for Australian iron ore also spiked this year.

Australia supplied a record 74 per cent of China's imported iron ore in June, according to trade figures, almost double the monthly average from 10 years ago. Over the last year, Australia has supplied 64 per cent of China's iron ore needs, up from 50 per cent just five years ago.

This spike was partly due to supply disruptions in Brazil but is still well up on figures of around 40 per cent at the height of the so-called "iron ore wars" in 2009, when Chinese leaders worried publicly about being too reliant on Australia.

Australian coking coal, used in steel making, supplied 40 per cent of China's imports in the first half of this year, second only to neighbouring Mongolia.

Earlier this year, there were some scares around coal import restrictions in China's north.

China also came up with a plan for its strategically important infant formula sector, which appeared to attempt to squeeze foreign players out of both ends of the supply chain.

The plan was to try to increase the government’s target for Chinese-produced formula, from about 47 per cent of the market to 60 per cent.

However, Australian National University's head of the East Asian Bureau of Economic Research, Peter Drysdale, said that on the whole the strength in trade was unperturbed by political rhetoric.

"We have had a trough in the political relationship with China in the last few years, yet the trade has continued to trade robustly," he said.

Goldman Sachs economist Andrew Boak said the relative risk of China changing its position on trade was likely a function of a combination of how easily China could substitute Australian goods and services, and how large a share Chinese demand of a given Australian good or service was.
description: Treasurer Josh Frydenberg says China's dependency on Australian imports will help maintain a peaceful trade balance with the superpower despite recent tensions around shared values.
